questions.explanation: 'Many of' is correct with definite article 'the'. 'Many' alone would be 'Many players', but 'Many of the players' specifies which players. Key takeaway: Many of + definite article + plural noun: many of the players.

questions.question: He jumped off the bus while it __________.
questions.explanation: Past continuous 'was moving' for ongoing action interrupted by 'jumped off'. The bus was in motion when he jumped. Remember: While + past continuous, simple past for interrupted action.

questions.question: When we got to the hall, the concert __________.
questions.explanation: Past perfect 'had already started' with adverb 'already' in middle position. The concert started before our arrival. Note: Adverb position: mid-position between auxiliary and main verb: had already started.

questions.question: The Eze __________.
options: has left about an hour ago
is leaving about an hour ago
had left about an hour ago
questions.explanation: Simple past 'left' with definite past time ('about an hour ago'). Present perfect cannot be used with definite past time expressions. Important: Simple past with definite past time: yesterday, last week, ago, in 1990.

questions.question: The teacher with his wife __________ here.
questions.explanation: With 'with', the verb agrees with the first subject ('the teacher' - singular), so 'is'. 'As well as' and 'along with' follow same rule. Remember: Subject + with/as well as/along with + noun, verb agrees with first subject.

questions.question: I __________ here until he comes.
questions.explanation: Future continuous 'shall be waiting' for action in progress at future time ('until he comes'). Emphasis on duration. Key takeaway: Future continuous: will/shall be + present participle for action in progress at future time.

questions.question: I would have been surprised if you __________ the apple.
questions.explanation: Mixed conditional: present result of past condition. 'Would have been' (present result) with 'if + past perfect' (past condition). Note: Mixed conditionals combine different time references.

questions.question: On getting to the seashore, __________.
questions.explanation: The dangling participle 'On getting' must modify the subject. 'He' must be the subject who got to the seashore. Remember: Participle phrases must logically modify the subject of the main clause.

questions.question: __________ him in the crowd, I would have told you at once.
questions.explanation: Inverted third conditional: 'Had I seen' = 'If I had seen'. The result is past unreal ('would have told'). Important: Inverted conditionals are more formal than regular conditionals.

questions.question: Before the bill could be settled, Chuwang __________ all the money.
questions.explanation: Past perfect 'had spent' for action completed before another past action ('could be settled'). Sequence: spent money → bill settlement attempted. Key takeaway: Before + past perfect, simple past for sequence.

questions.question: The effort made by the principal to get the students to be serious in their studies __________.
questions.explanation: Present simple passive 'is appreciated' because the subject 'effort' is singular and the appreciation is a general truth. Remember: Singular subject (effort) takes singular verb (is).

questions.question: When we got to the president's house, we were told that he __________ two days earlier.
questions.explanation: Past perfect 'had left' because his leaving occurred before the telling. Sequence: he left → we were told. Note: Reported speech often requires backshifting of tenses.

questions.question: Atuk, without giving any hint as to what he intended to do, went and __________ himself.
questions.explanation: 'Hanged' is the past tense for execution by hanging. 'Hung' is for objects. The context suggests suicide. Important: Hanged (people), hung (objects).

questions.question: Provided you __________ to the market very soon, we shall be able to eat early enough.
questions.explanation: 'Provided' introduces a real condition, so use present simple 'go' for future meaning (like 'if'). Remember: In conditional clauses (if, provided, unless), present simple can express future.

questions.question: He __________ by now; I can hear all the people shouting.
questions.explanation: 'Must have arrived' expresses logical deduction about the past based on present evidence ('I can hear'). Key takeaway: Must have + past participle = logical deduction about past.

questions.question: By the time the plane reaches Harare, it __________ in the air for twelve hours.
questions.explanation: Future perfect 'would have been' for duration up to future time. 'By the time' indicates future point. Note: Future perfect for duration: will/would have been + present participle.

questions.question: If only Adoyi __________ what was good for him he could easily have avoided the tragedy.
questions.explanation: 'If only' with past perfect expresses regret about past. 'Had known' refers to unreal past knowledge. Remember: If only + past perfect = regret about past.

questions.question: We saw Ifueko __________ an egg on the wall.
questions.explanation: After perception verbs (see, hear, watch), use base form (infinitive without to) for complete action. 'Saw her smash' means witnessed the entire action. Important: See/hear/watch + object + base verb (complete action) OR + present participle (ongoing action).

questions.question: Many streets in the town __________ in need of lights at night.
questions.explanation: Present simple 'stand' for general truth or permanent situation. This describes a current state, not temporary action. Note: Present simple for permanent situations/states.

questions.question: I did not enjoy the party. If you had invited Tariere, it __________ better organized.
questions.explanation: Third conditional again. Unreal past condition (you didn't invite) and past result (it wasn't better organized). Key takeaway: Third conditional for unreal past conditions and results.

questions.question: Sibi __________ novels since she came home.
questions.explanation: Present perfect continuous 'has been reading' for action starting in past and continuing to present ('since she came home'). Remember: Present perfect continuous emphasizes duration and ongoing nature.

questions.question: Asabe is overdue for retirement as she __________ in this college since 1954.
questions.explanation: Present perfect continuous 'has been teaching' for action starting in past (1954) and continuing to present. Important: Since + specific past time requires present perfect (continuous).

questions.question: If they had not all jumped out of the car just in time, they __________.
questions.explanation: Third conditional: unreal past condition (they jumped) and past result (they didn't perish). 'Would have perished' is correct. Note: 'Perish' doesn't normally take passive form ('been perished').

questions.question: Before mechanization, workers __________ water out of fabrics with their hands.
questions.explanation: 'Wrung' is the past tense of 'wring' (to twist and squeeze). Irregular verb: wring/wrung/wrung. Remember: Wring/wrung/wrung (twist/squeeze); Ring/rang/rung (sound).

questions.question: Four engineers __________ on this system since March.
questions.explanation: Present perfect continuous 'have been working' for action starting in past (March) and continuing to present. Key takeaway: Since + specific time requires present perfect (continuous).

questions.question: Having worked all night, the security man __________ a sense of accomplishment.
questions.explanation: Simple past 'felt' for completed action in the past. The perfect participle 'having worked' shows the work was completed first. Remember: Perfect participle (having + past participle) shows prior completion.

questions.question: __________ him around, I would have informed you.
questions.explanation: Inverted third conditional again. 'Had I seen' = 'If I had seen' (unreal past condition). Important: Inverted conditionals omit 'if' and invert subject and auxiliary.

questions.question: I have stopped writing letters of application because I __________ that all the vacancies are filled.
questions.explanation: Simple past 'heard' for specific past action that caused stopping. Present perfect would suggest ongoing hearing. Note: Simple past for specific completed past actions.

questions.question: It __________ easier if he told us himself.
questions.explanation: Second conditional: unreal present condition ('if he told' = he doesn't tell) and present result ('would be' = it isn't easy). Remember: Second conditional for unreal present situations.

questions.question: From a.m to 9 a.m, he __________ hot chocolate, often not having time for his own breakfast.
questions.explanation: Present simple passive 'is kept busy serving' for routine/habitual action. The schedule is regular. Key takeaway: Present simple for routines/schedules.

questions.question: It has been confirmed that the election __________ held in July.
questions.explanation: Future simple passive 'will be held' for future scheduled event. 'Has been confirmed' is present perfect, but election is future. Important: Future simple for scheduled future events.

questions.question: You should not need __________ twice.
questions.explanation: 'Need' as a main verb can take gerund with passive meaning. 'Need telling' = need to be told. Note: Need + gerund = need to be + past participle.

questions.question: The thief we caught yesterday was __________ as an official of the company.
questions.explanation: 'Disguised as' means dressed or made to look like someone else. A thief might disguise as an official. Remember: Disguised as = made to look like; Concealed = hidden.

questions.question: The trader complained that he __________ robbed.
questions.explanation: Past perfect 'had been robbed' because robbery occurred before the complaining. Sequence: was robbed → complained. Important: Reported speech often requires past perfect for earlier actions.

questions.question: Good schools don't just teach their students, they __________ them.
questions.explanation: 'Educate' means to develop mentally or morally through instruction. It's broader than just teaching or instructing. Key takeaway: Educate = develop whole person; Teach = impart knowledge; Instruct = give directions.

questions.question: If the boys arrived early enough, the match __________.
questions.explanation: First conditional (real future possibility). Structure: If + present simple, will + base verb. But here it's a variation. Remember: First conditional for real future possibilities.

questions.question: The keepers themselves are sometimes __________ by the bees.
questions.explanation: 'Stung' is the past participle of 'sting'. Irregular verb: sting/stung/stung. Note: Sting/stung/stung; Sing/sang/sung; Ring/rang/rung.

questions.question: I now realize I __________ you before.
questions.explanation: Present perfect 'have met' for past experience with present relevance ('I now realize'). Important: Present perfect for experiences with present relevance.

questions.question: The president of the union __________ for the airport by the time the riot started.
questions.explanation: Future perfect in the past 'would have left' for action completed before past time ('by the time the riot started'). Remember: Future perfect in the past: would have + past participle.

questions.question: I have decided to __________ drinking alcohol for health reasons.
questions.explanation: 'Give up' is the phrasal verb meaning to stop doing something, especially a habit. 'Give up drinking' is idiomatic. Key takeaway: Give up = stop (habit); Abandon = leave completely; Discard = throw away.

questions.question: One __________ be too careful these days; times are uncertain and walls have ears.
questions.explanation: 'Can't be too careful' is an idiom meaning it's impossible to be excessively careful. Remember: Can't be too + adjective = it's impossible to be excessively...

questions.question: My friend __________ me for many years when I met him last week.
questions.explanation: Past perfect 'had not seen' for action/state continuing up to past time ('when I met him'). Note: Past perfect for duration up to past point.

questions.question: School buildings that __________ in 1950 __________ now uninhabitable.
questions.explanation: Past passive 'were built' (1950 is past) and present 'are' uninhabitable (current state). Important: Build/built/built (irregular).

questions.question: __________, we can now start meaningful development.
options: Since the cold war is over
That the cold war is over
questions.explanation: 'With the cold war over' is an absolute construction (with + noun + participle). More concise than full clause. Remember: With + noun + participle = absolute construction showing circumstance.

questions.question: I hereby declare and __________ that, to the best of my knowledge, this statement is true in all respects.
questions.explanation: 'Affirm' means to state positively or declare firmly. Legal/official language often uses 'declare and affirm'. Key takeaway: Affirm = state positively; Confirm = verify; Conform = comply.

questions.question: __________ he would have been convicted.
questions.explanation: Third conditional: unreal past condition ('if he had done this' = he didn't do it) and past result ('would have been convicted'). Remember: Third conditional for unreal past situations.

questions.question: What saved her was that she __________ to the side of the boat.
questions.explanation: 'Clung' is the past tense of 'cling'. Irregular verb: cling/clung/clung. Note: Cling/clung/clung; Fling/flung/flung; Sling/slung/slung.

questions.question: He was __________ by the trickster.
questions.explanation: 'Duped' means deceived or tricked. A trickster would dupe someone. Important: Dupe = deceive/trick; Cajole = persuade with flattery.

questions.question: __________ I would have helped you.
options: Has it been that you asked me
Had it been that you asked me
questions.explanation: Third conditional: 'if you had asked me' (you didn't ask) and 'I would have helped' (I didn't help). Remember: Third conditional structure is fixed: If + past perfect, would have + past participle.

questions.question: I had hardly __________ down to sleep when I heard the gunshot.
questions.explanation: 'Lain' is the past participle of 'lie' (to recline). After 'had', need past participle: lie/lay/lain. Key takeaway: Lie/lay/lain (recline); Lay/laid/laid (put down).

questions.question: The protesters, unable to pull down the statue __________ it from its fixtures.
questions.explanation: 'Wrenched' means to pull or twist violently. Protesters might wrench a statue from its base. Note: Wrench = pull/twist violently; Tow = pull with rope/chain.

questions.question: With strong determination, Adamu was able to __________ the problem.
questions.explanation: 'Surmount' means to overcome or prevail over (a difficulty). Problems are surmounted. Important: Surmount = overcome; Surpass = exceed; Defend = protect.

questions.question: She sings __________.
questions.explanation: 'Beautifully' is an adverb modifying the verb 'sings'. Adverbs describe how an action is performed. Key takeaway: Adverbs often end in -ly and modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs.

questions.question: He drove __________ carefully to avoid the potholes.
questions.explanation: 'Extremely' is an adverb modifying another adverb 'carefully'. It intensifies the degree of carefulness. Note: Adverbs can modify other adverbs to show degree.

questions.question: The test was __________ difficult that few students passed.
questions.explanation: 'So' is an adverb of degree used with 'that' to show result. 'So difficult that' is the correct construction. Remember: So + adjective + that + clause (result).

questions.question: She __________ goes to the gym on weekends.
questions.explanation: 'Usually' is an adverb of frequency describing how often she goes to the gym. Important: Adverbs of frequency (always, usually, sometimes, never) show how often something happens.

questions.question: He arrived __________ for the meeting.
questions.explanation: 'Late' can function as both adjective and adverb. Here it's an adverb modifying 'arrived'. 'Lately' means recently. Key takeaway: Some words (fast, late, hard) can be both adjectives and adverbs without changing form.

questions.question: The children played __________ in the park.
questions.explanation: 'Happily' is an adverb describing how the children played. Most adverbs of manner are formed by adding -ly to adjectives. Remember: Adjective → Adverb: happy → happily, quick → quickly, careful → carefully.

questions.question: She spoke __________ softly that I could barely hear her.
questions.explanation: 'So' is an adverb of degree modifying 'softly'. 'So softly that' shows extreme degree with result. Note: So + adverb + that + clause.

questions.question: He works __________ than his brother.
questions.explanation: 'Harder' is the comparative form of the adverb 'hard'. It compares how two people work. Important: Comparative adverbs: hard → harder, fast → faster, well → better.

questions.question: She __________ visits her grandparents.
questions.explanation: 'Often' is an adverb of frequency. It doesn't take -ly ending. Remember: Some frequency adverbs don't end in -ly: often, seldom, never, always.

questions.question: He ran __________ to catch the bus.
questions.explanation: 'Quickly' is the adverb form describing how he ran. Most adjectives add -ly to form adverbs. Key takeaway: Quick (adjective) → quickly (adverb).

questions.question: The team performed __________ in the championship.
questions.explanation: 'Excellently' is an adverb modifying 'performed'. Some adjectives ending in -ent form adverbs with -ly. Note: Excellent → excellently, different → differently.

questions.question: She looked at him __________.
questions.explanation: 'Strangely' is an adverb describing how she looked. After verbs of perception (look, seem, appear), adverbs describe the action. Remember: Look (verb) + adverb describes how you look at something.

questions.question: He finished the race __________.
questions.explanation: 'First' functions as an adverb here, describing when he finished. Ordinal numbers can be adverbs. Important: First, second, third can function as adverbs.

questions.question: The baby slept __________ through the night.
questions.explanation: 'Peacefully' is an adverb modifying 'slept'. It describes how the baby slept. Key takeaway: Peaceful (adjective) → peacefully (adverb).

questions.question: She __________ completed her assignment.
questions.explanation: 'Nearly' is an adverb meaning almost. It modifies the verb 'completed'. Note: Some adverbs have different meanings from their adjective forms: near (close) → nearly (almost).

questions.question: He answered the question __________.
questions.explanation: 'Correctly' is an adverb describing how he answered. Most adjectives add -ly to form adverbs. Remember: Correct (adjective) → correctly (adverb).

questions.question: They arrived __________ at the party.
questions.explanation: 'Punctually' is an adverb meaning exactly on time. It describes how they arrived. Important: Punctual (adjective) → punctually (adverb).

questions.question: She sang __________ beautifully than anyone else.
questions.explanation: 'More' is an adverb forming the comparative of 'beautifully'. Adverbs of two or more syllables use 'more' for comparative. Key takeaway: More + adverb (comparative), most + adverb (superlative).

questions.question: He spoke __________ during the interview.
questions.explanation: 'Confidently' is an adverb describing how he spoke. Adjectives ending in -ent often form adverbs with -ly. Note: Confident → confidently, different → differently.

questions.question: The car moved __________ down the hill.
questions.explanation: 'Slowly' is the standard adverb form. 'Slow' can be adverb informally, but 'slowly' is preferred in formal writing. Remember: Slow (adjective/adverb informal) → slowly (adverb formal).

questions.question: She __________ goes to bed before midnight.
questions.explanation: 'Rarely' is an adverb of frequency meaning not often. It modifies the verb 'goes'. Important: Rare (adjective) → rarely (adverb).

questions.question: He solved the puzzle __________ quickly.
questions.explanation: 'Surprisingly' is an adverb modifying 'quickly'. It describes the degree or manner of quickness. Key takeaway: Surprising (adjective) → surprisingly (adverb).

questions.question: They worked __________ to finish the project on time.
questions.explanation: 'Diligently' is an adverb describing how they worked. Adjectives ending in -ent form adverbs with -ly. Note: Diligent → diligently, intelligent → intelligently.

questions.question: The bird flew __________ across the sky.
questions.explanation: 'Gracefully' is an adverb modifying 'flew'. It describes how the bird flew. Remember: Graceful (adjective) → gracefully (adverb).

questions.question: She __________ remembered her childhood friend.
questions.explanation: 'Suddenly' is an adverb describing when she remembered. It indicates something happened unexpectedly. Important: Sudden (adjective) → suddenly (adverb).

questions.question: She has a __________ voice.
questions.explanation: 'Beautiful' is an adjective modifying the noun 'voice'. Adjectives describe nouns. Key takeaway: Adjectives modify nouns and pronouns.

questions.question: This is the __________ book I've ever read.
questions.explanation: 'Most interesting' is the superlative adjective. 'The most interesting' shows the highest degree. Note: Superlative adjectives: the + most + adjective (for long adjectives).

questions.question: He seems __________ today.
questions.explanation: 'Happy' is an adjective after the linking verb 'seems'. Linking verbs take adjectives, not adverbs. Remember: Linking verbs (seem, appear, become, look) are followed by adjectives.

questions.question: She bought a __________ dress for the party.
questions.explanation: 'Beautiful red' follows the adjective order rule: opinion (beautiful) before color (red). Important: Adjective order: opinion, size, age, shape, color, origin, material, purpose.

questions.question: This problem is __________ than I thought.
questions.explanation: 'More difficult' is the comparative adjective. Adjectives of two or more syllables use 'more' for comparative. Key takeaway: Comparative adjectives: more + adjective (for long adjectives).

questions.question: The __________ children played in the park.
questions.explanation: 'Excited' is an adjective describing people's feelings. -ed adjectives describe how people feel. Remember: -ed adjectives (excited, bored, tired) describe feelings; -ing adjectives (exciting, boring, tiring) describe things.

questions.question: It was an __________ movie.
questions.explanation: 'Amazing' is an adjective describing the movie. -ing adjectives describe things or situations. Note: The movie is amazing (describes the movie).

questions.question: She has __________ hair.
questions.explanation: 'Long black' follows adjective order: size (long) before color (black). Important: Size comes before color in adjective order.

questions.question: This is a __________ opportunity.
questions.explanation: 'Golden' is the adjective form meaning valuable or excellent. Some nouns form adjectives with -en. Key takeaway: Some adjectives from nouns: gold → golden, wood → wooden, silk → silken.

questions.question: He is __________ person I know.
questions.explanation: 'The kindest' is the superlative adjective. One-syllable adjectives add -est for superlative. Remember: Superlative: the + adjective + -est (for short adjectives).

questions.question: The __________ flowers bloom in spring.
questions.explanation: 'Colorful' is an adjective describing the flowers. -ful suffix often forms adjectives. Note: Color → colorful, beauty → beautiful, wonder → wonderful.

questions.question: She felt __________ after the long journey.
questions.explanation: 'Exhausted' is an -ed adjective describing her feeling. People feel exhausted; journeys are exhausting. Important: -ed adjectives for people's feelings; -ing adjectives for things causing feelings.

questions.question: This is __________ cake I've ever tasted.
questions.explanation: 'The best' is the irregular superlative of 'good'. Good has irregular forms: good → better → best. Key takeaway: Irregular adjectives: good → better → best; bad → worse → worst.

questions.question: He gave a __________ speech.
questions.explanation: 'Powerful' is an adjective modifying 'speech'. -ful suffix forms adjectives meaning 'full of'. Remember: Power → powerful, hope → hopeful, thought → thoughtful.

questions.question: The weather was __________ yesterday.
questions.explanation: 'Pleasant' is an adjective describing the weather. -ant suffix often forms adjectives. Note: Please → pleasant, differ → different, import → important.

questions.question: She has __________ eyes.
questions.explanation: 'Big blue' follows adjective order: size (big) before color (blue). Important: Size adjectives come before color adjectives.

questions.question: This is a __________ decision.
questions.explanation: 'Difficult' is an adjective modifying 'decision'. Some adjectives don't change form. Key takeaway: Difficult (adjective), difficulty (noun), difficultly (adverb).

questions.question: He looks __________ in that suit.
questions.explanation: 'Handsome' is an adjective after linking verb 'looks'. 'Looks' as linking verb takes adjective. Remember: Look + adjective (appearance), look + adverb (action of looking).

questions.question: The __________ child won the competition.
questions.explanation: 'Talented' is an -ed adjective describing the child. Past participles can function as adjectives. Note: Many past participles function as adjectives: bored, interested, excited, tired.

questions.question: It was a __________ performance.
questions.explanation: 'Memorable' is an adjective meaning worth remembering. -able suffix forms adjectives meaning 'able to be'. Important: Memory → memorable, comfort → comfortable, value → valuable.

questions.question: She bought __________ furniture for her new apartment.
questions.explanation: 'Some' is a quantifier adjective used with uncountable noun 'furniture'. Key takeaway: Some for uncountable nouns in affirmative sentences; any for questions/negatives.

questions.question: This is __________ interesting book.
questions.explanation: 'An' is the indefinite article used before vowel sound. 'Interesting' starts with vowel sound /ɪ/. Remember: Use 'an' before vowel sounds, not just vowel letters.

questions.question: He has __________ friends in this city.
questions.explanation: 'Many' is a quantifier adjective used with countable plural noun 'friends'. Note: Many for countable nouns; much for uncountable nouns.

questions.question: She gave me __________ advice.
questions.explanation: 'Some' is a quantifier adjective used with uncountable noun 'advice'. Important: Advice is uncountable; use some, not a/an or many.

questions.question: This is __________ important meeting.
questions.explanation: 'An' is used because 'important' starts with vowel sound /ɪ/. The 'h' in 'hour' is silent, so it takes 'an'. Key takeaway: Use 'an' before silent h: an hour, an honor, an honest person.

questions.question: She is interested __________ learning French.
questions.explanation: 'In' is the correct preposition with 'interested'. 'Interested in' is the fixed prepositional phrase. Key takeaway: Interested in + noun/gerund.

questions.question: He apologized __________ being late.
questions.explanation: 'For' is the correct preposition with 'apologized'. 'Apologize for' something is the correct collocation. Note: Apologize to someone for something.

questions.question: She is good __________ mathematics.
questions.explanation: 'At' is the correct preposition with 'good'. 'Good at' indicates skill or ability in a subject. Remember: Good at (skill), good with (people/tools), good for (beneficial).

questions.question: We arrived __________ the airport at 6 PM.
questions.explanation: 'At' is used for specific points or locations like airports, stations, addresses. Important: At for specific points; in for areas/cities/countries.

questions.question: She is afraid __________ spiders.
questions.explanation: 'Of' is the correct preposition with 'afraid'. 'Afraid of' is the fixed expression. Key takeaway: Afraid of + noun/gerund.

questions.question: The book is __________ the table.
questions.explanation: 'On' indicates surface contact. A book resting on a table uses 'on'. Note: On for surfaces, in for containers, at for points.

questions.question: He is married __________ a doctor.
questions.explanation: 'To' is the correct preposition with 'married'. 'Married to' someone is the correct expression. Remember: Married to (person), married with (children).

questions.question: She is looking __________ her keys.
questions.explanation: 'For' indicates searching or seeking. 'Looking for' means trying to find. Important: Look for (search), look at (observe), look after (take care of).

questions.question: They are talking __________ the weather.
questions.explanation: 'About' indicates topic or subject. 'Talk about' a topic is correct. Key takeaway: Talk about (topic), talk to/with (person).

questions.question: The cat jumped __________ the wall.
questions.explanation: 'Over' indicates movement from one side to the other. Jumping over a wall implies crossing it. Note: Over implies crossing; above implies higher position without crossing.

questions.question: She is fond __________ chocolate.
questions.explanation: 'Of' is the correct preposition with 'fond'. 'Fond of' means liking something. Remember: Fond of, proud of, afraid of.

questions.question: He succeeded __________ passing the exam.
questions.explanation: 'In' is the correct preposition with 'succeeded'. 'Succeed in doing something' is correct. Important: Succeed in + gerund.

questions.question: We are waiting __________ the bus.
questions.explanation: 'For' indicates expectation or anticipation. 'Wait for' someone or something. Key takeaway: Wait for + noun; wait to + verb.

questions.question: She is proud __________ her son's achievements.
questions.explanation: 'Of' is the correct preposition with 'proud'. 'Proud of' is the fixed expression. Note: Proud of, ashamed of, jealous of.

questions.question: He lives __________ London.
questions.explanation: 'In' is used for cities, towns, and countries. London is a city, so 'in' is correct. Remember: In for areas (cities, countries); at for points (addresses, specific locations).

questions.question: She is similar __________ her mother.
questions.explanation: 'To' is the correct preposition with 'similar'. 'Similar to' is the fixed expression. Important: Similar to, different from, same as.

questions.question: The picture is hanging __________ the wall.
questions.explanation: 'On' indicates attached to a surface. Pictures hang on walls. Key takeaway: On for surfaces where something is attached or resting.

questions.question: He is responsible __________ the accident.
questions.explanation: 'For' is the correct preposition with 'responsible'. 'Responsible for' something means being the cause. Note: Responsible for (thing), responsible to (person/authority).

questions.question: She is listening __________ music.
questions.explanation: 'To' is the correct preposition with 'listening'. 'Listen to' something is the fixed phrase. Remember: Listen to (sound/music/person), listen for (specific sound).

questions.question: The meeting will start __________ 9 AM.
questions.explanation: 'At' is used for specific times. 9 AM is a specific time point. Important: At for specific times; on for dates/days; in for months/years/seasons.

questions.question: She is angry __________ her brother.
questions.explanation: 'With' is used for people when expressing anger. 'Angry with' someone. Key takeaway: Angry with (person), angry about/at (situation).

questions.question: He is famous __________ his paintings.
questions.explanation: 'For' indicates reason or cause of fame. 'Famous for' something means known because of it. Note: Famous for (achievement), famous as (role/identity).

questions.question: The keys are __________ the drawer.
questions.explanation: 'In' indicates inside a container or enclosed space. A drawer is an enclosed space. Remember: In for containers; on for surfaces.

questions.question: She is worried __________ her exam results.
questions.explanation: 'About' indicates concern regarding something. 'Worried about' is the correct expression. Important: Worried about, anxious about, concerned about.

questions.question: He arrived __________ Monday morning.
questions.explanation: 'On' is used for specific days and dates. Monday is a specific day. Key takeaway: On for days/dates; at for times; in for months/years.

questions.question: The primary cause of all these accidents __________ driver negligence.
questions.rule_focus: Basic Rule (Singular Subject with Intervening Phrase)
questions.explanation: The real subject is **'cause'** (singular). We ignore the phrase 'of all these accidents'. A singular subject needs a singular verb: **is**.

questions.question: The students in the advanced class __________ preparing for the final presentation.
questions.explanation: The main subject is **'students'** (plural). A plural subject needs a plural verb: **are**.

questions.question: An excellent display of traditional masks and crafts __________ arranged in the main hall.
questions.explanation: The action is about the **'display'** (singular), not the 'masks and crafts'. We ignore the phrase 'of...'. The singular verb **is** is correct.

questions.question: The journalist, as well as the camera crew, __________ arriving at the scene shortly.
questions.explanation: Phrases like 'as well as' don't change the subject count. The verb agrees only with the first subject, **'The journalist'** (singular). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Our competitors, and not our own team, __________ benefited from the regulatory change.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the subject that is *not* crossed out, which is **'Our competitors'** (plural). The plural verb **have** is correct.

questions.question: The ship, with all its passengers and cargo, __________ heading for the open sea.
questions.explanation: The phrase 'with all its passengers...' is extra information. The main subject is **'The ship'** (singular). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Neither the coach nor the players __________ prepared for the championship.
questions.explanation: When using 'neither... nor', the verb must agree with the subject that is **closest to it**: **'the players'** (plural). Use the plural verb **were**.

questions.question: Either the committee members or the chairman __________ to approve the final budget.
questions.explanation: When using 'either... or', the verb must agree with the subject **closest to it**: **'the chairman'** (singular). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Not only the main hall but also the offices __________ in need of urgent renovation.
questions.rule_focus: Correlative Conjunctions (Not only... but also - Plural proximity)
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the closest subject, **'the offices'** (plural). Use the plural verb **are**.

questions.question: Both the marketing team and the sales director __________ agreed on the strategy.
questions.explanation: The structure **'Both... and'** always joins two things, making the subject plural. Use the plural verb **have**.

questions.question: If I am not going, then my brother or my sisters __________ going.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the subject closest to it, **'my sisters'** (plural). Use the plural verb **are**.

questions.question: Either the workers or the manager __________ to take responsibility for the error.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the subject closest to it, **'the manager'** (singular). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Each of the candidates __________ submitted a detailed proposal.
questions.explanation: Indefinite pronouns like **'Each'**, 'Every', 'Anyone', 'Nobody', etc., are always singular. Ignore 'of the candidates'. Use the singular verb **has**.

questions.question: Every seat and every aisle in the theater __________ been checked for safety.
questions.explanation: The word **'Every'** forces the whole subject (seat and aisle) to be treated as singular. Use the singular verb **has**.

questions.question: Everyone who completed the assignment __________ eligible for extra credit.
questions.explanation: The indefinite pronoun **'Everyone'** is always singular. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Nobody in the surrounding villages __________ seen anything unusual.
questions.explanation: The indefinite pronoun **'Nobody'** is always singular. Use the singular verb **has**.

questions.question: Several of the items on the menu __________ changed since last year.
questions.explanation: Indefinite pronouns like **'Several'**, 'Both', 'Few', and 'Many' are always plural. Use the plural verb **have**.

questions.question: Many a candidate __________ the true meaning of the party's manifesto.
questions.explanation: The phrase **'Many a'** is an exception and always requires a singular noun and a **singular verb**: **fails to grasp**.

questions.question: Neither of the two solutions __________ completely satisfactory.
questions.explanation: The indefinite pronoun **'Neither'** is always singular. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The whole cast of the play __________ travelling together on the bus.
questions.explanation: A collective noun like **'cast'** is treated as one single unit when the group acts together. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The jury __________ still deliberating on the verdict.
questions.explanation: The collective noun **'jury'** is typically treated as a singular unit when acting together (deliberating one verdict). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The board of directors __________ unable to agree on a single course of action.
questions.explanation: The verb **were** is used because the members of the **'board'** are acting individually (they couldn't 'agree'). The focus is on the members, not the unit.

questions.question: Mumps __________ still considered a serious illness for adults.
questions.explanation: Names of diseases that end in 's' (like **'Mumps'**, *measles*) are treated as singular nouns. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Economics __________ often described as the dismal science.
questions.rule_focus: Nouns Plural in Form (Academic Discipline - Singular)
questions.explanation: Academic subjects ending in 's' (like **'Economics'**, *Physics*) are treated as singular nouns. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Five hundred dollars __________ not enough to cover the tuition fee.
questions.explanation: When an amount of money or time (**'Five hundred dollars'**) is seen as a single, fixed unit, it is treated as singular. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The police __________ arrived at the scene of the accident.
questions.explanation: The word **'police'** is always treated as plural. Use the plural verb **have**.

questions.question: Two-thirds of the employees __________ given a holiday bonus this year.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* the fraction. **'employees'** is plural, so the verb must be plural: **were**.

questions.question: One-third of the city's infrastructure __________ damaged by the recent flood.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* the fraction. **'infrastructure'** is uncountable (singular), so the verb must be singular: **is**.

questions.question: Seventy percent of the club members __________ voted against the new rule.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* the percentage. **'club members'** is plural, so the verb must be plural: **have**.

questions.question: Most of the paperwork for the merger __________ completed yesterday.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* the quantifier. **'paperwork'** is uncountable (singular), so the verb must be singular: **was**.

questions.question: None of the money collected for the charity __________ yet to be deposited.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* 'None of'. **'money'** is uncountable (singular), so the verb must be singular: **is**.

questions.question: All of the computers in the laboratory __________ running the latest software.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* 'All of'. **'computers'** is plural, so the verb must be plural: **are**.

questions.question: The laptop and the projector __________ necessary tools for the presentation.
questions.explanation: Two separate things joined by **'and'** (**'laptop'** and **'projector'**) always create a plural subject. Use the plural verb **are**.

questions.question: Bread and butter __________ my favourite meal on Fridays.
questions.explanation: When two subjects joined by 'and' represent a single, fixed idea or dish (**'Bread and butter'**), they take a singular verb. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The principal and academic director of the school __________ resigned today.
questions.explanation: Since the article **'The'** is only used once (before 'principal'), the sentence refers to one person holding both jobs. Use the singular verb **has**.

questions.question: The novelist and poet, who is also my neighbour, __________ giving a lecture tonight.
questions.explanation: The single use of the article 'The' before **'novelist'** indicates that the subject is one person holding two titles, requiring the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: He is one of the managers who always __________ tasks to subordinates.
questions.explanation: The pronoun 'who' refers to the plural word **'managers'**. Therefore, the verb must be plural: **delegate**.

questions.question: She is the only one of the applicants who __________ all the qualifications.
questions.rule_focus: Relative Pronouns ('The Only One' - Forces Singularity)
questions.explanation: The words **'the only one'** restrict the meaning, forcing the pronoun 'who' to refer to the singular word **'one'**. Use the singular verb **meets**.

questions.question: The ancient carving that __________ in the museum __________ over a thousand years old.
questions.explanation: The main subject **'carving'** is singular. Both the verb in the relative clause and the main verb must be singular: **is displayed/is**.

questions.question: These are the issues that __________ the most attention from the public.
questions.explanation: The relative pronoun 'that' refers to the plural antecedent **'issues'**. The verb must be plural: **deserve**.

questions.question: The decision is one of the important factors that ultimately __________ the project's success.
questions.explanation: The relative pronoun 'that' refers to the plural antecedent **'factors'**. The verb must be plural: **determine**.

questions.question: There __________ only one possible solution to this complex problem.
questions.explanation: In sentences starting with 'There' or 'Here', the verb agrees with the word *following* the blank. The subject is **'one possible solution'** (singular). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: There __________ several unexpected complications during the surgery.
questions.explanation: The subject is **'several unexpected complications'** (plural). Use the plural verb **were**.

questions.question: Here __________ the keys for your new apartment.
questions.explanation: The subject is **'the keys'** (plural). Use the plural verb **are**.

questions.question: The classic film *Jaws* __________ still terrifying audiences decades later.
questions.explanation: The title of a single work (*Jaws*) is always treated as **singular**, even if the words inside are plural. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: His new book of essays, *Ideas and Paradoxes*, __________ a difficult read for most students.
questions.explanation: The subject is the singular head noun **'book'**. The title, *Ideas and Paradoxes*, is treated as a single unit. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The phrase 'All is fair in love and war' __________ often misused in casual speech.
questions.explanation: A quoted phrase used as a subject is always treated as a **singular unit**. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Linguistics __________ the scientific study of language and its structure.
questions.rule_focus: Nouns Plural in Form (Academic Discipline - Singular)
questions.explanation: Academic subjects ending in 's' (**'Linguistics'**) are singular concepts. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The committee members, not the leader, __________ responsible for the final presentation.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the subject that is *not* crossed out, which is **'The committee members'** (plural). Use the plural verb **are**.

questions.question: All the necessary scissors and tweezers __________ packed in the first aid kit.
questions.explanation: Nouns for paired items (**'scissors'** and **'tweezers'**) are always treated as **plural** (like pants or glasses). Use the plural verb **were**.
